| A wood golem:* [does not breathe](/wiki/Breathless "Breathless").

* has a [thick hide](/wiki/Thick-skinned "Thick-skinned").
* [does not eat](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate"). (\*)
* is neither male nor female.
* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").
* [never leaves a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless"). |                                                      |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |                                                      |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         | [monst.c#line2064](/wiki/Monst.c#line2064 "Monst.c") |

A **wood golem**, ', is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The wood golem is the slowest of the [golems](/wiki/Golem "Golem"), and is [thick-skinned](/wiki/Thick-skinned "Thick-skinned") - weapons that use the [axe](/wiki/Axe "Axe") skill deal +d4 bonus damage against wood golems.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

A wood golem has a single claw attack, and possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") and [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") like all golems. A wood golem that is subjected to [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") will become a [stone golem](/wiki/Stone_golem "Stone golem").[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Wood golems that take damage from [fire traps](/wiki/Fire_trap "Fire trap"), the fire effect of [magic traps](/wiki/Magic_trap "Magic trap") and the fire effect of [container traps](/wiki/Container_trap "Container trap") can lose maximum [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") up to 1⁄4 of that maximum plus one;[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) a wood golem that is hit by a decay attack (i.e. from a [brown pudding](/wiki/Brown_pudding "Brown pudding")) will instantly rot away and be destroyed.[\[5\]](#cite_note-RIP-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) A [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a wood golem can lose the same amount of maximum HP from the aforementioned traps, and dying from a decay attack returns them to normal form, even if they are wearing an [amulet of unchanging](/wiki/Amulet_of_unchanging "Amulet of unchanging").[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.3 FIQHack](#FIQHack)
  - [6.4 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [6.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.6 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated wood golems are always created hostile. Wood golems are always generated with 40 [HP](/wiki/HP "HP").[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

Wood golems can generate as a result of [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") if there are enough [wood](/wiki/Wood "Wood") objects in a pile of items.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

Wood golems leave behind 2-8 [quarterstaves](/wiki/Quarterstaves "Quarterstaves") upon death [instead of a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless").[\[11\]](#cite_note-11) They are not a valid target for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit e5c73d01](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/e5c73d01fefff13d49d9af83a52615dfe20e2699), wood golems have a chance of also dropping [small shields](/wiki/Small_shield "Small shield"), [clubs](/wiki/Club "Club"), [elven spears](/wiki/Elven_spear "Elven spear"), and [boomerangs](/wiki/Boomerang "Boomerang") alongside quarterstaves upon death.

## Strategy

Despite a decently strong claw attack for the point of the game they can be first encountered, wood golems are quite slow at 3 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") and are unlikely to be a threat to most heroes. Be careful not to create a wood golem by accident when polypiling your highly-enchanted [elven weapons and armor](/wiki/Elven_item "Elven item").

## History

The wood golem is introduced in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including some variants based on those versions, casting [stone to flesh](/wiki/Stone_to_flesh "Stone to flesh") at a [statue](/wiki/Statue "Statue") or [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of a golem produces a single [meatball](/wiki/Meatball "Meatball"), since any golem other than the [flesh golem](/wiki/Flesh_golem "Flesh golem") or [leather golem](/wiki/Leather_golem "Leather golem") is considered "[vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian "Vegetarian")" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") via [commit d8a0f734](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4) so that doing so produces a live flesh golem.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Golem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golem "wikipedia:Golem")***

The *gōlem* is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

The [encyclopedia](/wiki/Encyclopedia "Encyclopedia") entry for the wood golem is an excerpt from ["The Sorcerer's Apprentice"](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sorcerer%27s_Apprentice "wikipedia:The Sorcerer's Apprentice"), a 1797 balled written by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. In the poem, an old sorcerer departs his workshop, leaving his apprentice with chores to perform; when the apprentice tires of fetching water by pail, he enchants an old broomstick to do the work for him, but is not fully trained in this magic - he soon finds he cannot stop the broom, and attempting to chop it apart with an [axe](/wiki/Axe "Axe") simply results in two animate brooms forming instead. Before long, the entire room quickly begins to flood, and when all seems lost the old sorcerer returns and quickly breaks the spell, telling the apprentice that only a master should invoke powerful spirits.

## Messages

- \<The wood golem> falls to pieces!

  A wood golem was hit by a rotting attack and killed instantly.[\[5\]](#cite_note-RIP-5)

- May \<pet> rot in peace.

  A pet wood golem was killed as above, while out of your range of sight.[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)

## Variants

In variants with [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") systems, wood golems may drop additional wooden items upon death alongside or instead of a pile of quarterstaves.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), wood golems are generated with 100 HP, possess [death resistance](/wiki/Death_resistance "Death resistance") and [hit as a +1 weapon](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon").[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)[\[14\]](#cite_note-14) This also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

### dNetHack

[dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack") add the [living lectern](/wiki/Living_lectern "Living lectern"), an animated spellbook on a wooden stand that is somewhat similar to a wooden golem.

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), the wood golem's glyph is changed to *'*.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), wood golems can drop various items with an [object material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(xNetHack\) "Object materials (xNetHack)") of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, [small shield](/wiki/Small_shield "Small shield"), [club](/wiki/Club "Club"), [elven spear](/wiki/Elven_spear "Elven spear"), or a [boomerang](/wiki/Boomerang "Boomerang").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), wood golems can drop various items with an [object material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(EvilHack\) "Object materials (EvilHack)") of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, small shield, club, elven spear, or a boomerang.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), wood golems can drop various items with an [object material](/index.php?title=Object_materials_\(Hack%27EM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Object materials (Hack'EM) (page does not exist)") of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, small shield, club, elven spear, or a boomerang.

## Encyclopedia entry

Come, old broomstick, you are needed,  
Take these rags and wrap them round you!  
Long my orders you have heeded,  
By my wishes now I've bound you.  
Have two legs and stand,  
And a head for you.  
Run, and in your hand  
Hold a bucket too.  
...  
See him, toward the shore he's racing  
There, he's at the stream already,  
Back like lightning he is chasing,  
Pouring water fast and steady.  
Once again he hastens!  
How the water spills,  
How the water basins  
Brimming full he fills!

\[ The Sorcerer's Apprentice, by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe,  
 translation by Edwin Zeydel ]

14. [↑](#cite_ref-14) [monst.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 3528](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line3528 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c")

Wood golem

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
' wood golem
Difficulty 8
Attacks Claw 3d4
' wood golem
Difficulty 8
Attacks

Claw 3d4

Base level 7
Base experience 92
Speed 3
Base AC 4
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable No
Weight 900
Nutritional value 0
Size Large
Resistances sleep, poison
Resistances conveyed None

A wood golem:

  • does not breathe.
  • is mindless.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • has a thick hide.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • never leaves a corpse.
Reference monst.c#line2064

A wood golem, ', is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. The wood golem is the slowest of the golems, and is thick-skinned - weapons that use the axe skill deal +d4 bonus damage against wood golems.[1][2]

A wood golem has a single claw attack, and possesses poison resistance and sleep resistance like all golems. A wood golem that is subjected to stoning will become a stone golem.[3]

Wood golems that take damage from fire traps, the fire effect of magic traps and the fire effect of container traps can lose maximum HP up to 1⁄4 of that maximum plus one;[4] a wood golem that is hit by a decay attack (i.e. from a brown pudding) will instantly rot away and be destroyed.[5][6] A hero polymorphed into a wood golem can lose the same amount of maximum HP from the aforementioned traps, and dying from a decay attack returns them to normal form, even if they are wearing an amulet of unchanging.[7][8]

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Messages
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM

    • 6.3 FIQHack

    • 6.6 Hack'EM
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry

Generation

Randomly-generated wood golems are always created hostile. Wood golems are always generated with 40 HP.[9]

Wood golems can generate as a result of polypiling if there are enough wood objects in a pile of items.[10]

Wood golems leave behind 2-8 quarterstaves upon death instead of a corpse.[11] They are not a valid target for genocide.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Per commit e5c73d01, wood golems have a chance of also dropping small shields, clubs, elven spears, and boomerangs alongside quarterstaves upon death.

Strategy

Despite a decently strong claw attack for the point of the game they can be first encountered, wood golems are quite slow at 3 speed and are unlikely to be a threat to most heroes. Be careful not to create a wood golem by accident when polypiling your highly-enchanted elven weapons and armor.

History

The wood golem is introduced in NetHack 3.0.0. From this version to NetHack 3.4.3, including some variants based on those versions, casting stone to flesh at a statue or figurine of a golem produces a single meatball, since any golem other than the flesh golem or leather golem is considered "vegetarian" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in NetHack 3.6.0 via commit d8a0f734 so that doing so produces a live flesh golem.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Golem

The gōlem is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

The encyclopedia entry for the wood golem is an excerpt from "The Sorcerer's Apprentice", a 1797 balled written by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. In the poem, an old sorcerer departs his workshop, leaving his apprentice with chores to perform; when the apprentice tires of fetching water by pail, he enchants an old broomstick to do the work for him, but is not fully trained in this magic - he soon finds he cannot stop the broom, and attempting to chop it apart with an axe simply results in two animate brooms forming instead. Before long, the entire room quickly begins to flood, and when all seems lost the old sorcerer returns and quickly breaks the spell, telling the apprentice that only a master should invoke powerful spirits.

Messages

<The wood golem> falls to pieces!
A wood golem was hit by a rotting attack and killed instantly.[5]
May <pet> rot in peace.
A pet wood golem was killed as above, while out of your range of sight.[12]

Variants

In variants with object materials systems, wood golems may drop additional wooden items upon death alongside or instead of a pile of quarterstaves.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, wood golems are generated with 100 HP, possess death resistance and hit as a +1 weapon.[13][14] This also applies to SlashTHEM.

dNetHack

dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack add the living lectern, an animated spellbook on a wooden stand that is somewhat similar to a wooden golem.

FIQHack

In FIQHack, the wood golem's glyph is changed to '.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, wood golems can drop various items with an object material of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, small shield, club, elven spear, or a boomerang.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, wood golems can drop various items with an object material of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, small shield, club, elven spear, or a boomerang.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, wood golems can drop various items with an object material of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, small shield, club, elven spear, or a boomerang.

Encyclopedia entry

Come, old broomstick, you are needed,
Take these rags and wrap them round you!
Long my orders you have heeded,
By my wishes now I've bound you.
Have two legs and stand,
And a head for you.
Run, and in your hand
Hold a bucket too.
...
See him, toward the shore he's racing
There, he's at the stream already,
Back like lightning he is chasing,
Pouring water fast and steady.
Once again he hastens!
How the water spills,
How the water basins
Brimming full he fills!

[ The Sorcerer's Apprentice, by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe,
 translation by Edwin Zeydel ]

A '''wood golem''', {{monsym|wood golem}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. The wood golem is the slowest of the [[golem]]s, and is [[thick-skinned]] - weapons that use the [[axe]] skill deal +d4 bonus damage against wood golems.{{refsrc|include/mondata.h|79|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/weapon.c|324|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

A wood golem has a single claw attack, and possesses [[poison resistance]] and [[sleep resistance]] like all golems. A wood golem that is subjected to [[stoning]] will become a [[stone golem]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|2525|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Wood golems that take damage from [[fire trap]]s, the fire effect of [[magic trap]]s and the fire effect of [[container trap]]s can lose maximum [[HP]] up to {{frac|4}} of that maximum plus one;{{refsrc|src/trap.c|2411|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} a wood golem that is hit by a decay attack (i.e. from a [[brown pudding]]) will instantly rot away and be destroyed.{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1118|version=NetHack 3.6.7|name="RIP"}}{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|1875|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} A [[hero]] [[polymorph]]ed into a wood golem can lose the same amount of maximum HP from the aforementioned traps, and dying from a decay attack returns them to normal form, even if they are wearing an [[amulet of unchanging]].{{refsrc|src/mhitu.c|1458|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/trap.c|3158|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Generation==
Randomly-generated wood golems are always created hostile. Wood golems are always generated with 40 [[HP]].{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1981|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Wood golems can generate as a result of [[polypiling]] if there are enough [[wood]] objects in a pile of items.{{refsrc|src/zap.c|1316|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Wood golems leave behind 2-8 [[quarterstaves]] upon death [[Corpseless|instead of a corpse]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|400|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} They are not a valid target for [[genocide]].

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Per {{commit|e5c73d01fefff13d49d9af83a52615dfe20e2699}}, wood golems have a chance of also dropping [[small shield]]s, [[club]]s, [[elven spear]]s, and [[boomerang]]s alongside quarterstaves upon death.}}

==Strategy==
Despite a decently strong claw attack for the point of the game they can be first encountered, wood golems are quite slow at 3 [[speed]] and are unlikely to be a threat to most heroes. Be careful not to create a wood golem by accident when polypiling your highly-enchanted [[Elven item|elven weapons and armor]].

==History==
The wood golem is introduced in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. From this version to [[NetHack 3.4.3]], including some variants based on those versions, casting [[stone to flesh]] at a [[statue]] or [[figurine]] of a golem produces a single [[meatball]], since any golem other than the [[flesh golem]] or [[leather golem]] is considered "[[vegetarian]]" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in [[NetHack 3.6.0]] via {{commit|d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4}} so that doing so produces a live flesh golem.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Golem}}
The ''gōlem'' is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

The [[encyclopedia]] entry for the wood golem is an excerpt from [[wikipedia:The Sorcerer's Apprentice|"The Sorcerer's Apprentice"]], a 1797 balled written by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. In the poem, an old sorcerer departs his workshop, leaving his apprentice with chores to perform; when the apprentice tires of fetching water by pail, he enchants an old broomstick to do the work for him, but is not fully trained in this magic - he soon finds he cannot stop the broom, and attempting to chop it apart with an [[axe]] simply results in two animate brooms forming instead. Before long, the entire room quickly begins to flood, and when all seems lost the old sorcerer returns and quickly breaks the spell, telling the apprentice that only a master should invoke powerful spirits. 

==Messages==
{{message|<The wood golem> falls to pieces!|A wood golem was hit by a rotting attack and killed instantly.<ref name="RIP"/>}}
{{message|May <pet> rot in peace.|A pet wood golem was killed as above, while out of your range of sight.{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1125|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}}}

==Variants==
In variants with [[object materials]] systems, wood golems may drop additional wooden items upon death alongside or instead of a pile of quarterstaves.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], wood golems are generated with 100 HP, possess [[death resistance]] and [[Hits creatures as +x weapon|hit as a +1 weapon]].{{refsrc|makemon.c|2249|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|monst.c|3528|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} This also applies to [[SlashTHEM]].

===dNetHack===
[[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]] add the [[living lectern]], an animated spellbook on a wooden stand that is somewhat similar to a wooden golem.

===FIQHack===
In [[FIQHack]], the wood golem's glyph is changed to {{brown|<u>'</u>}}.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], wood golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (xNetHack)|object material]] of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, [[small shield]], [[club]], [[elven spear]], or a [[boomerang]].

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], wood golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (EvilHack)|object material]] of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, small shield, club, elven spear, or a boomerang.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], wood golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (Hack'EM)|object material]] of wood upon death - any invalid objects generated this way are each replaced with a quarterstaff, small shield, club, elven spear, or a boomerang.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
Come, old broomstick, you are needed,
Take these rags and wrap them round you!
Long my orders you have heeded,
By my wishes now I've bound you.
Have two legs and stand,
And a head for you.
Run, and in your hand
Hold a bucket too.
...
See him, toward the shore he's racing
There, he's at the stream already,
Back like lightning he is chasing,
Pouring water fast and steady.
Once again he hastens!
How the water spills,
How the water basins
Brimming full he fills!
|[ The Sorcerer's Apprentice, by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe,
 translation by Edwin Zeydel ]
}}
